job_title: Lifeguard in Calabasas, CA
pros: I really loved it here, it's amazing
cons: I can't imagine anything bad

review_title: Mixed Experience at CalArts - Pros and Cons
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Valencia, CA
pros: Creative Environment: CalArts fosters a highly creative and artistic environment, which can be inspiring for individuals passionate about the arts. Mission and Impact: CalArts' commitment to artistic innovation and educational excellence contributes to its positive impact on the arts community.
cons: Lack of Communication: Communication channels between management and employees could be improved. There were instances where important information or updates were not effectively communicated, leading to confusion and frustration. Limited Growth Opportunities: While CalArts provides an enriching work environment, growth opportunities for career advancement can be limited, particularly in certain departments. Inadequate Performance Evaluations: During my tenure, performance evaluations were not conducted or provided, which made it challenging to gauge progress and receive constructive feedback. Training and Development: The availability of professional development programs and training resources was insufficient, hindering employee growth and skill enhancement.

job_title: Adjunct Lecturer in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Fantastic colleagues and students make this a delightful job.
cons: Salary unless you negotiate is the same whether you have one year experience, two or ten. Not everyone can negotiate.

job_title: Writing Center Tutor in Santa Clarita, CA
pros: The people running the writing center are great. the hours are pretty flexible but you only get 3 hours of work a week. it’s a great college job and the people you make connections with through tutoring is very rewarding.
cons: Limited hours for shift work and someone running the training is not very knowledgeable on cultural sensitivity.

job_title: Technical Specialist in Santa Clarita, CA
pros: - employer values your artistic practice - 5 creative leave days per year - possibility to teach technical courses as needed - immersive artist community at staff, faculty and student level - access to state of the art equipment - technical staff has union support
cons: - Frequent facility issues due to age of building

job_title: Teaching Assistant in Santa Clarita, CA
pros: Flexible work timing. Great teacher
cons: Under paid sometimes in certain departments

review_title: Good Pay Rate, Bad Number of Hours
job_title: Graduate Student Employee in Santa Clarita, CA
pros: The minimum payment is $15, which is great. Your bosses are very friendly and willing to work with you to ensure your success.
cons: You get very minimal hours per week, averaging at most 8-10 hrs a week. There are a lot of communication challenges across the institute.

review_title: Incredible School - Student Workers Make Minimum Wage
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Valencia, CA
pros: An unbelievably unique, dynamic, one-of-kind, collaborative, enriching institution with world-class instruction in dozens of artistic disciplines.
cons: Unfortunately, student workers are paid minimum wage, even for teaching valuable private lessons to university students. The answer they give for this is that this is the maximum rate allowed for work study, which I believe, however I still must protest as it is just simply far, far below the rate that such important work should be valued at and I believe the school could find a way to mend this, at least for special cases. It is good to have this teaching experience on the resume, of course.

job_title: Senior Concert Technician in Valencia, CA
pros: The people are great, the work is rewarding and you get so much experience your resume is filled. Great mentors that tech you the job patiently and efficiently
cons: From lowest to highest level of technician, you’re earning minimum wage, even if you’re training 3 people at once.

job_title: Accounting Manager in Santa Clarita, CA
pros: location, teachers, community, and students
cons: upper executives which are too many

job_title: Administrative Assistant in Valencia, CA
pros: Nice pace of work, days off for holidays
cons: The average pay "looks" decent but that's only because of select senior leadership and faculty who are paid triple, quadruple, and beyond most staff salaries. The average staff makes lower than any surrounding colleges.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Santa Clarita, CA
pros: Interesting faculty, engaged students, top-notch equipment
cons: Poorly managed, out of touch administration, pitiful compensation of student workers

job_title: Image Services in Valencia, CA
pros: Helpful boss really eager to see employees improve skills and helps with finding new jobs
cons: very repetitive work, limited room for growth

job_title: Special Faculty in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Some incredible students, dedicated teaching team
cons: Admissions process feels arbitrary which makes teaching challenging and labor-intensive, NO org chart to rely on in times of crisis, NO clear support structure for victims of harassment, increasingly diminishing pay, very little work-life balance, incredibly stressful work environment, very little job security, constant feeling that one might lose their job at any second. In short, a hostile, toxic environment that promotes overwork by making employees feel as if they are never doing enough.

job_title: Teaching Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Experience teaching alongside and observing great educators.
cons: Salary is low and hours are limited.

job_title: Dance Instructor in Chatsworth, CA
pros: I worked as a TA and Social Media Manager for the Dance school. It was a learning experience.
cons: I have none at the moment.

review_title: Have you tried a hard reboot?
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Valencia, CA
pros: Incredible creativity and talent everywhere — found among students, faculty, and staff.
cons: Culture of FEAR, currently…People-pleasing and politicking is killing us. No one in power has the guts to address the siloed (and in some cases toxic) workplace cultures that have developed over time within Schools, divisions, or offices.

review_title: Engaging, pioneering art institution to work for
job_title: Director of Career Services in Santa Clarita, CA
pros: Creative liberty, collaboration, open-mindedness, sensitivity to employee and student needs, friendly office environment
cons: Ever-changing operations, new voices, and changing directions in administrative expectations and arrangements

job_title: Production Manager in New York, NY
pros: good job school work easy
cons: not the best pay but doable

job_title: Day Labor in Santa Clarita, CA
pros: Creative cool people, interesting projects, lots of opportunity to learn new skills
cons: no direct deposit, weird hours to pick up checks, administration office woman quite rude

job_title: Community Arts Partnership Lead Teacher in Valencia, CA
pros: The work of the Community Arts Partnership is rewarding. As a graduate student at CalArts, I had the opportunity to directly invest my technique and skills into young students and future creative thinkers in public schools. It is a valuable way to apply your artistic knowledge and a rewarding way to learn from young arts students.
cons: Some of these positions are only available to current CalArts students.

job_title: Faculty in Santa Clarita, CA
pros: Great students. A lot of great work. Committed faculty & staff.
cons: Cost cutting is eroding the faculty, staff, and even the building.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in Santa Clarita, CA
pros: Every Friday off in the summer
cons: low pay, low morale, dungeon like setting

review_title: Fun and Collaborative - Terrible pay for Staff
job_title: Administrative Assistant in Valencia, CA
pros: Great coworkers. Administration appears to be attempting to remedy the equity issues Staff face.
cons: Staff pay is significantly lower than Faculty, and the Faculty is not paid well either. There is no merit pay, no step program, and people who have been here for many years with no raise. Faculty members have a step and merit program.

job_title: Dance Teacher/Choreographer in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Freedom to shape curriculum as you please
cons: the pay is low for level of expertise

job_title: Director, Board Relations in Valencia, CA
pros: It's a place where magic happens and people love the Institute.
cons: It's going through a series of transitions that promote growing pains.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: if you’re a student this Is a great place to work
cons: it pays below minimum wage

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Valencia, CA
pros: collaborative community, exciting students and faculty
cons: constant pressure to add more and more work

job_title: Work Study Student in Santa Clarita, CA
pros: flexible schedule with school work
cons: can be busy at times

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Valencia, CA
pros: Amazing creative environment with a lot of freedom. Incredibly talented teaching professionals. A very determined and dedicated student body. It's a great atmosphere to be a teacher in while also pursuing professional goals.
cons: Most of the upper management, and the administrative leaders in particular, are very out of touch with the original vision of the school. The campus is being run more like a for-profit business rather than focusing on being a pioneer in the arts. This effects the students as well as the faculty. Because of the huge operational budget, more faculty are laid off than administrative workers, which creates a greater strain on the remaining faculty and widens the teacher:student class ratio.

review_title: Logistical mess, but paid well for the position
job_title: Graduate Student Teaching Assistant in Valencia, CA
pros:
- Comparatively good pay for the hours you work (supposedly 8 hours/week)
- Get teaching experience while being trained in some pedagogy
- Get to experience a more traditional teacher role in the first semester, then a more traditional TA role in the second semester
cons:
- Can't pay overtime due to the nature of the contract
- Because some professors and many supervisors are disorganized, your work as a TA can take a lot longer than 8 hours every week
- No one seems to take the larger disorganization at CalArts seriously or the fact that it negatively impacts student experience, so you may feel like you're being gaslit if you bring up concerns

review_title: Some fantastic people caught in a system that lacks direction and leadership
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Valencia, CA
pros: There are some very talented people here, it's a creative-academic atmosphere
cons: The school lives off of its past history as a groundbreaking, cutting edge art school; the technology is behind other schools, managers settle for status quo, lack of creativity on the part of the administration; the good people leave from burnout, the bad people stay because there is no performance bars set.

review_title: The Character Animation Department -- A very creative and inspiring place to be.
job_title: Instructor in Valencia, CA
pros:
The pay is very good compared to the other colleges I've taught at, twice as much as some (!)

The present department heads have made the program much better-run, better structured, and changed the previous all-too-laissez faire attitude of the students and department into one that gives the teachers much more motivated and responsible pupils to teach (which makes our job much easier).

The other teachers are top-notch talents in the field and almost everyone I've met over the years is very dedicated to helping the students be the best that they can.
cons: Not really any.  There's occasionally slow progress on getting change to happen in a class or the program but no more than so than in any higher ed bureaucracy.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Valencia, CA
pros: Creative, collaborative students and faculty and an infectious spirit of exploration permeate the air. Supportive team mentality among staff across the Institute fosters people not only working hard but working smart. CalArts is a magical environment in which to make art and to work. I have experienced this place as a student, instructor, part-time employee, and full-time employee; I have been impressed and thrilled by the experiences at every stage. With many new faces at the helms of major departments and programs, budget transparency, new initiatives, emphasis on institute diversity, and many other exciting developments, it is a thrilling time to work at and serve CalArts. Every go-getter who studies and works here has the opportunity to thrive amid our action-packed academic and extracurricular calendars and our ambitious programming on- and off-campus. Staff appreciation week, great available benefits, many work perks, and so many aspects of working and studying here make staff and alumni feel earnestly appreciated. As a full-time employee and member of the CalArts alumni community, I am so grateful that the school emphasizes a healthy work-life balance for its staff and students who pursue dual career pathways working here and working separately as artists.
cons: The overall structures, peer support, work ethic, and team mentalities here are strong, but there is a short list of a few outliers among staff and faculty whose attitudes and procedures can be described as territorial or stubbornly set in unconstructive ways.

review_title: An okay job to have during school.
job_title: Resident Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
-Most flexible on campus job
-Usually a good group of people to work with that you get close with
-Looks good on resumes
-Pays fairly well, and includes a free room
-Guaranteed summer employment and housing working for the summer program
cons:
-Management can be fickle, sometimes outright incompetent
-Office is run by very tech-resistant employees
-The job involves dealing with students, and a lot of the students can be incredibly rude and self-entitled.

review_title: Lay back, very uncorporate, yet backwards as far as technology and pay
job_title: Administrative Assistant in Valencia, CA
pros: Working with students, seeing artwork made by students.  Very casual, relaxed atmosphere.  We have the opportunity to vote and have Fridays off during the summer which rocks!
cons: Pay is low, benefits poor.  No raise this year.  Ability to promote within or outside the department is almost impossible.

job_title: Employee in Santa Clarita, CA
pros: The benefits are the one and only pro
cons:
The following are based on my personal experiences at CalArts, and don’t necessarily reflect the experience(s) of any other employees. 

•Homophobic environment in certain departments
•Apathetic and unresponsive HR department
•Numerous Cal-OSHA work safety violations, such as emergency exit hallways clogged with obstacles and equipment 
•Crumbling infrastructure 
•Bloated bureaucracy 
•Low pay
•I have personally been yelled at by the VP/COO for voicing displeasure in my job, and I quote, “If it’s so terrible here, then why do you still work here?” Obviously, he didn’t want an answer
•A building that was never actually finished
•Lack of any empathy or candid communication from upper management
•Lots of unpaid missed breaks 
•Lots of unpaid overtime 
•No fire suppression system in the dilapidated dorm building (181 dorm rooms, with an average of 2 to a room) and the smoke detectors in the dorm rooms are not wired into the fire alarm system, but there was more than enough money to revamp the cafeteria dining room and install a pizza oven
•Regular and severe plumbing issues
•Prison-grade restrooms in some areas
•The most disgusting, foul smelling cafeteria kitchen I have ever seen
•Seemingly never ending asbestos abatement, which raises a lot of questions about exposure levels here
•The main fire alarm annunciator constantly has unresolved faults that cause it to be in alarm for literally, and I mean literally in the literal sense, years at a time
•It seems like there is almost a caste system with administrators, management, and faculty vying for supremacy, while staff get the leftovers, when there are any. This applies doubly to employees throughout the Facilities Department, who suffer below industry standard pay, yet are under immense scrutiny at all times. At least that’s how it feels. 

This is not a safe, welcoming, or even livable environment to work in long term, in my opinion

job_title: Teaching Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: I like working there. such a vibrant school.  the management listens to your opinion sincerely and they are very open-minded.
cons: i guess valencia is a bit far too drive from the city.  sometimes you ll get a lot of traffic when you hit the I-5.  especially morning hours or at around 5 you will hit the jam.

job_title: Teaching Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: It was a wonderful job.
cons: Simply that I would have liked to have been able to work there more, since the job was so nice.

job_title: Student Worker in San Diego, CA
